repnme.cdata!:
Uganda - District Health Services Pilot and
            Demonstration Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The audit ratings differ slightly from
            the Implementation Completion Report's (ICR), i.e.,
            project outcome is upgraded to moderately unsatisfactory
            from an unsatisfactory rating, while the institutional
            development impact is downgraded to substantial from a high
            rating; yet, it concurs on a likely sustainability, and, on
            an unsatisfactory Bank performance, but satisfactory
            Borrower performance. Lessons convey the following. Pilot
            and demonstration approaches to reform implementation will
            not automatically generate or document a learning process,
            nor will such approaches necessarily lead to a fine-tuning
            of reforms in light of experience, if they are not well
            prepared and if they are not fully understood and owned by
            Government and other stakeholders. Important ingredients to
            a successful pilot include: the definition of the learning
            agenda; the definition of the pilot process, including the
            use of evaluation for scaling-up; a clear and coherent
            monitoring and evaluation framework, including indicators,
            tools and methodologies; the availability of essential
            inputs; a realistic timetable; and strong social and
            political commitment. The absence of a clear and coherent
            results framework (clearly stated objectives, well-chosen
            indicators and a well-defined results chain, linking inputs,
            outputs, outcomes and impact) is likely to cause confusion
            among national stakeholders and compromise national
            understanding and commitment, especially when the project is
            complex and is supporting far-reaching reforms. Importantly,
            adequate attention must also be given to assessing the
            political feasibility of projects.

6761616.trustfund:
TF020052-DISTRICT HEALTH SERVICES PILOT
            & DEMON. PROJECT,TF029146-PHRD-AIDS & HEALTH REFORM,TF030306-CANADIAN (GEN) CTF FY03 -
            HEALTH NUTRITION AND POPULATION,TF034914-EASTERN AFRICA REGION - HEALTH
            SECTOR REFORM PROJECTS (TANZANIA -,TF036503-AFRICA REGION - HEALTH,
            NUTRITION AND POPULATION,TFM20052-DISTRICT HEALTH SERVICES PILOT

abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, given that it was not
            successful in achieving its major objectives of testing and
            demonstrating the feasibility of delivering an essential
            health services package, but did make a contribution to
            policy-making  and planning, as well as capacity building at
            central and district level, and, arguably, paved the way for
            the  coming together of partners in a sector-wide approach,
            the project's achievement is rated as partially
            satisfactory. Despite the problems with the project, and the
            resultant mixed outcomes, the sustainability of the project
            activities - from the programmatic as well as the financial
            perspective - is rated as likely. This assessment is based
            on the fact that the institutions in Uganda, helped by the
            DHSP, are now stronger and the donors  are working
            collaboratively with the government of Uganda and each
            other, within an overall development framework. Given the
            unsatisfactory performance of the Bank at project
            identification, preparation, appraisal and for  part of the
            supervision, and despite the observed improvement in project
            supervision in the latter half of the  project, the
            Bank's overall performance must be rated as
            unsatisfactory. Overall Borrower performance is assessed as
            partially satisfactory. The project was co-funded by the
            Government of Sweden and the Government of the Federal
            Republic of Germany: partner performances were both rated
            satisfactory. Lessons learned included the following: 1) The
            project was implemented at a time when Uganda was just
            recovering  from conflict and internal strife, and
            furthermore had embarked on an ambitious decentralization
            agenda that sought to devolve the responsibility for the
            planning and implementation of essential public  services,
            including health, to district administrations. Such
            devolution of power presents several  unique challenges for
            the design and implementation of Bank supported sectoral
            projects, that need to  be recognized and effectively
            managed, but which were underestimated by the project. 2)
            The project was conceived and designed as a  traditional
            project, but ended up providing broad programmatic support
            and gradually developing a  larger group of development
            partners. The absence of a clear government sectoral policy
            compounded the situation. This raises substantial questions
            about the use of a traditional project as the instrument for
            major sectoral and institutional reform. 3) To be fully
            effective, reform efforts within the health sector need to
            explicitly recognize the politics and political economy of
            the sector; the potential constraints imposed by other
            ongoing reforms; and the need for early and extensive
            consultations with relevant stakeholders in order to ensure
            wide ownership. 4) The project worked with decentralized and
            community-based  organizations, which was a strong
            achievement. However, nongovernmental organizations (NGOs)
            were constrained by having to work  through Local Tender
            Boards. 5) Projects such as this one that work with multiple
            implementing  partners, such as districts, sub-district
            entities, and community-based organizations, faith-based
            organizations, and NGOs need to make multiple advances to
            those implementing partners and thus require correspondingly
            larger Special Accounts. 6) A viable and effective
            monitoring and evaluation framework mutually agreed upon at
            the time of project  preparation is essential. 7) Effective
            donor coordination is vital for the improved performance of
            the health sector.

repnme.cdata!:
Uganda - District Health Services Pilot and
            Demonstration Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the District Health
            Services Pilot and Demonstration Project is to pilot-test
            and demonstrate the feasibility of delivering an essential
            health services package to district populations, within a
            prudent financial policy framework for the sector in order
            to improve the efficiency and equity in the provision of
            health services. The project is designed to support the
            Government's strategy of decentralizing health
            services. It plans to increase the efficiency of the
            existing health infrastructure and institutions through
            consolidation and improved management with increased local
            accountability, while simultaneously supporting cost
            recovery and budgetary policies that will enable the health
            care system to move toward long term sustainability. It
            supports the Government's efforts to reorder priorities
            within the exisitng health care system through efficiency
            improvements and by reallocating financial and human
            resources toward ensuring the provision of a package of
            essential health services for all Uganda's citizens.
            Accordingly, the proposed project will: 1) pilot and test
            new sector policies and strategies which will facilitate the
            implementation of essential health services; 2) strengthen
            management and planning capacity at district levels so that
            they are prepared to provide essential health services; and
            3) restructure the Ministry of Health so as to build its
            capacity to provide health policy leadership and to support
            the Government's decentralization policy.

Uganda - District Health Services Pilot and
